awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Biofluid Dynamics of the Human Breast: Characterization and Fluid-Structure Interaction
awd_abstract_narration:
1454334
Hassanipour

The goal of this CAREER proposal is to study lactation in the human breast from a fluid dynamics point of view, considering the flow of milk as flow through a porous medium with flexible structure. Despite the scientific importance and impact on public health, bio-transport processes in the human breast have not been comprehensively studied, and are currently not well-understood. This is the white space that the current proposal aims to cover, with potential impact on the lives of millions of people. Success of the project can enable biomedical devise design and diagnosis of health conditions related to the female breast. This project has the potential for high rewards, since it can open up a completely new area of research. The societal and economic impact of understanding fundamentally the fluid-structure interaction in the human breast can be very significant, ranging from effective drug delivery to health condition diagnosis and the design of medical devises  resolving lactation difficulties. 

The PI is proposing to use state-of-the-art experiments and simulations to understand the bio-transport behavior of the ductal system of the human breast. Advanced imaging and 3D printing techniques are going to be used to obtain realistic images of the pore structure within human breasts and then to manufacture prototypes for laboratory and computational investigation of the flow. The breast-infant interaction and the boundary effects of infant suckling will also be investigated. The proposed research activities are further integrated with an educational component including course development, and K-12 outreach activities that are a continuation of PI's past work with high-school students.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit of this funded activity includes answering fundamental questions regarding the biomechanics of breastfeeding, including the process of infant suckling with its many constituent parts, and the anomalies in lactation and breastfeeding, as well as human milk generation and milk composition. Several mathematical models of the human breast and milk production, as well as computer generated modeling of the breast and breastfeeding, and a bio-inspired breastfeeding simulator, have been developed leveraged by novel in-vivo clinical measurements and in-vitro experimentation.

The clinical study of the biomechanics of human breast produced a solid quantitative understanding of the infant suckling biomechanics during breastfeeding. The key to this study was a novel deployment of thin pressure sensors and synchronous data fusion with ultrasound and vacuum sensor. This resulted in measurements that led to highly novel insights on the biomechanics of feeding, including forces produced on the breast by the complex periodic motions of the mouth, tongue, palate, and jaw of the infant, and their effect on milk expression.

The computational modeling of lactating breast led to development of a 3-D  computer generated model for breastfeeding mechanism that include not only the pulsating sucking (vacuum) pressure, but also the solid deformation and periodic motion of the tongue and jaw movement (compression). The computational approach opens a window into phenomena that are difficult to experimentally observe or measure in real-time during breastfeeding, including the flow behavior of milk inside the ducts during breastfeeding.

The mathematical modelling study describes the milk mass transfer from alveolar sacs through mammary ducts to the nipple, analyzing both the diffusion phenomena in the sacs and conventional flow in the ducts. This work clarified certain relationships between biological variables (e.g. diameter of alveolar sacs and bifurcations in the breast duct network) and physical parameters (e.g. milk flow).

A realistic programmable Bio-Inspired Breastfeeding Simulator (BIBS) apparatus is developed for both the infant suckling (including motions of the palate, tongue, and jaw, and sucking pressure), as well as a model of human breast with milk-mimicking liquid (in terms of flow properties) that allows external observations of flow. BIBS is designed and constructed based on CT scanned images of the infants' oral cavity and the clinical measurements. The fully-developed mechanical breastfeeding simulator provides a valuable tool for understanding the biomechanics of breastfeeding in vitro and provides a foundation for future breastfeeding device development.

Broader Impacts of this research have a profound impact on a wide set of medically related outcomes, from the development of medical and health-related devices (e.g. infant feeding assistive device) to the diagnosis and treatment of diseases (e.g. blocked milk ducts and mastitis). The results of the NSF-CAREER project have been widely disseminated via invited talks, and conferences, and journal papers.

This fund has (in part) supported 10 PhD students (five female), 10 undergraduate students (five female and one of them a female student with disability) and 6 high school students (four female). Among many, the accomplishment of NSF-sponsored students include co-authorship of papers, as well as several best paper awards, travel grants to participate in conferences and NSF fellowship, such as: NSF GRFP fellowship, NSF GRIP, NSF INTERN, two best paper awards in ASME-IMECE Conferences, winner of the flow visualization award in AJKFluids conferences, and People?s Choice award in the Three Minute Thesis competition. 


Last Modified: 01/03/2023
Modified by: Fatemeh Hassanipour
